awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Taphonomy, Paleopathology and Mortuary Variability in Chaco Canyon: Using Modern Methods to Understand Ancient Cultural Practices
awd_abstract_narration:
Under the supervision of Dr. John Verano, Ms. Kerriann Marden will conduct the final phase of her analysis of the skeletal series from the pre-Columbian site of Pueblo Bonito, Chaco Canyon.  Located in northwest present-day New Mexico, Chaco Canyon is believed to have been the origin and epicenter of a broad prehispanic culture system. Pueblo Bonito is the largest and most centrally positioned of the massive "Great Houses" in the canyon, yet the function of this structure remains debated.  Excavations of  Pueblo Bonito in the late 19th and early 20th century revealed burial chambers containing dozens of human remains, many of which were disordered and commingled, giving rise to much speculation about who these people were and why their bodies had been treated in this manner.  Ms. Marden's research employs an array of current methods of skeletal analysis to advance understanding of the cultural practices and social organization of this important Chaco Great House.

For this final phase of research, Ms. Marden will return to the American Museum of Natural History to complete analysis of the remains that she reassociated on previous visits. Bioarchaeological analysis (the application of skeletal analysis to archaeological materials) is most instructive when examining bodies as complete organisms, providing information about the forces acting upon that individual both in life and after death. Reassociation of remains allows an accurate assessment of the number, age, sex, nutritional status, disease markers and mortuary treatment of the individuals buried in this important Great House.  Bioarchaeology and paleopathology (the study of ancient disease processes) offer insight into an individual's nutrition, health and overall quality of life.  In contrast, taphonomy (the study of postmortem changes) provides information about the manner in which a body was treated at and after death.  Lastly, stable isotope analysis and radiocarbon dating will help to locate these remains temporally and geographically to elucidate who was buried at Pueblo Bonito, which will help to determine the function of this massive Great House.  The data collected in this final phase of research will be compared with equivalent data Marden has collected from Pueblo Bonito remains housed at the National Museum of Natural History, the Field Museum and the Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology.  These concatenated data will provide a common framework to interpret how relative health status and/or social status may have influenced mortuary behavior at this enigmatic pre-Columbian site.

The proposed research will have a broader impact on several levels. Since the canyon was the epicenter of the Chacoan system and influenced culture groups throughout the region, an understanding of cultural practices at the core site of Pueblo Bonito offers a key to understanding a broad swath of prehispanic Southwest culture.  Furthermore, this research will contribute to the betterment of the museum collections and impact future research by enhancing documentation of collections. Documentation of Native American physical anthropology collections is becoming especially important with the increasing likelihood of repatriation of these remains. Ms. Marden's research will aid in reconstructing the development of Chacoan society, both now and in future research-- even after these remains are no longer available for direct observation.

por.por_cntn:
This doctoral dissertation research explored the ways in which an individual’s social status and/or health condition may have influenced the way their body was treated in death at Pueblo Bonito, Chaco Canyon. Located in northwest present-day New Mexico, Pueblo Bonito is among the largest and most centrally located “Great Houses,” massive stone buildings characteristic of the pre-Hispanic Chaco culture system which extended throughout and beyond the pre-Hispanic San Juan River Basin. Excavations at Pueblo Bonito in the 1890s by the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) and 1920s by the National Museum of Natural History (NMNH) revealed clusters of burial chambers containing dozens of human remains. The purpose of the Great Houses—residential, ritual, economic, political or other—remains debated, but since some of these burial rooms (now in the collections of the AMNH) included tremendous amounts of turquoise and other exotic materials, such as bear claws, sea shells, and carved jet, it was widely accepted that these were the tombs of elite members of Chacoan society. However, the bones of many of the burials in this Great House appeared to be in disarray, particularly those in the collections of the NMNH. The juxtaposition of a wealth of grave goods and disordered burials has been interpreted in a variety of ways, ranging from pre-Hispanic grave robbing to a socially stratified society within the Great House of Pueblo Bonito.

The present study is an attempt to provide a better explanation for the condition of these burials through a comprehensive examination of the Pueblo Bonito human skeletal collections of the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) and chemical analyses of a sample of the skeletal remains in the collections of the National Museum of Natural History (NMNH). All of the commingled skeletal remains in these collections were first reassociated (restored to discrete individuals) in order to make an accurate assessment of the number, age, sex, nutritional status, disease markers, and burial treatment of the individuals entombed in this important Great House. Analysis of the complete human skeleton provides information about the forces acting upon that individual both in life and after death. Bioarchaeology (the application of skeletal analysis to archaeological materials) and paleopathology (the study of ancient disease processes) offer insight into an individual’s nutrition, health and overall quality of life, which may in turn influence the way in which a body is handled at the end of life. In contrast, taphonomy (the study of postmortem changes) provides information about the manner in which the body was treated at and after death. Taken together, bioarchaeology, paleopathology and taphonomy can inform archaeological interpretation by exploring the relative health status of individuals buried in a particular cultural context and recognizing differences or similarities in mortuary treatment.

Chemical analyses allow us to determine details about an individual’s life history, including dietary habits (Carbon-13 and Nitrogen-15 stable isotopes) and where they grew up (Strontium-87 and Oxygen-18 stable isotopes). Conducting these analyses of the remains in the NMNH collection allowed us to make comparisons with existing data from the AMNH collections and to test hypotheses that the AMNH collections represent a group of social elites at Pueblo Bonito.

Comparison of radiocarbon dates of these two collections indicate that the individuals in the two burial clusters of Pueblo Bonito were of entombed during the same time period, and strontium and oxygen stable isotope analysis showed that they were all of local origin, rather than outsiders who moved into the region. Dietary analyses of carbon and nitrogen stable isotopes suggest relatively uniform dietary practices not only among those buried in the two clusters of Pueblo Bonito, but also amongst individuals sampled throughout the canyon. Lastly, the bioarcheological analysis indicates that—aside from the quantity of exotic grave goods—burial treatment of the individuals in these two clusters was very similar, and that those buried in the Great House did not experience better overall health or protection from disease than those found in smaller Chaco Canyon sites.

The overall results of this research suggest that the burials at Pueblo Bonito did not enjoy a better lifestyle or better health than people buried elsewhere in Chaco Canyon, and that the reason for their burial in this Great House may be something other than an elite social status, as previously believed. Since Pueblo Bonito is considered “ground zero” of the Chacoan system and influenced culture groups throughout the Four Corners region, an understanding of cultural practices at the Great House offers a key to understanding a broad swath of pre-Hispanic Southwest culture. The data and analysis resulting from this study not only enrich understanding of Ancestral Puebloan cultures, but also improve the documentation of collections of all five museums.
